_exec_summary.SummaryText: The Ed Love watre treatment facility is one of two water treatment plants owned and operated by the City of Tuscaloosa with the Jerry Plott Plant being a membrane plant that utilizes sodiumhypochlorite for disinfectant. The City of Tuscaloosa has a population of 90,000 people and water services for 170,000 people in the metropolitan area.                                                                                                                                                                                        Tuscaloosa is the home of the University of Alabama, Stillman College, Mercedes Benz, JVC America, Hunt refinery and B.F. Goodrich tire manufacturing. There are numerous industries in the 300 to 700 employee range that also make their home in Tuscaloosa. The diverse industry has contributed to a very pleasant life style inTuscaloosa.                                                The Ed Love Plant is a 45.7 million gallon per day treatment plant that consists of aluminum sulfate (ALUM) for coagulation, lime for pH control, fluoride for tooth decay prevention, chlorine for disinfectant and orthopolyphosphate for corrosion inhibtor.                                                                                                                                                                                   The source water for the plant is Lake Tuscaloosa that has a capacity of 40 billion ghallons and is a very clean water source. Raw water turbidity averages around 6.0 NTU. The backup to Lake Tuscaloosa is Lke Nicol, a four billion gallon lake and Lake Harris a one billion gallon lake.                                                                                                                                                                                       The water filtration plant is in an urban setting with the University of Alabama less than one mile from the facility. DCH hospital, Tuscaloosa Middle School, Hampton Inn, student apartments,

churches and offices, University Mall, Bryce Hospital for the Menatly challenged and Taylor Hardin Facility for the Criminaly insane are all within 1.5 miles of the plant.                                                                                                                                                                                      The treatment plant utilizes chlorine in disinfecting to prevent protozoa, viruses that are present in water as well as coliformsand bacteria. The plant has two one ton cylinders that are on line and connected to a common header and consume 1200 lbs per day at maximum capacity of plant. The chlorine is in liquid form and is vaporized and fed into the post chemical mixer and into the finished water.                                                                                                                                                                                       Maintenance operators and plant operators  work daily on changing chlorine cylinders and follow the procedures for RMP for changing cylinders.Maintenance personnel check all lines from the valves on chlorine cylinders that connect the valve to the manifold feed. As cylinders are being changed out, the exhaust vent is energized to remove any fumes from the chlorine room. All operators and maintenance personnel check self contained air supply and protective clothing in case there is a discharge. The scrubber is filled with a 12% solution of sodium hydroxidev (NaOH) in order to neutralize the chlorine. The concentration of the chlorine is checked monthly in order to maintain the 12% concentration. The scrubber has the capacity to withstand a one ton release.                                                                                                                                                                                    All esential personnel are trained in chlorine safety and may repair minor problems such as a leaking gasket, rupture

ed lines and amall spills. An outside chlorine manufacuture or distributors presents a training seminar on the use and handling of chlorine at the Ed Love Plant each year. Training tapes are reviewed on a regular basis for chlorine safety and all new employees go through a training prrogram for chlorine safety.                                                                                                                                                                                      In case of a worst case scenario, and the plant experienced a major discharge, the LEPC, fire station two and four  and the police are immediately notified. All non-essential personnel are evactuated to prevent injuries and loss of life. At the discretion of the LEPC, HAZMAT, teams, police department and prevaling winds conditions, a decision is made as to what areas are evactuated to a predetermined safe distance. The release of gas will be contained to the to the best of everyone's ability as a HAZMAT team works to neautralize the discharge. After the discharge has been neautralized, an assessment will be made as to the extent of the damage, injuries or loss of life if applicable. The Ed love water Treatment Facility has no releases in the last five years and has never had a major release.                                                                                                                                                                                    Theree are 32 full time employees at the Ed Love Plant and the plant is owned and subsidized by the City of Tuscaloosa. The City of Tuscaloosa consists of a city council and mayor form of government with six(6) city council members and a mayor. The city government approves budgets for the water treatment plant and all cost that are incurred as far as meeting regulatory compliance. It is important that the city stay abreast of all compliance, regulations and laws that are enacted that will impact the city as far as wate

r quality and changes in said quality.                                                                                                                                                                                     The city recently buil a new membrane plant with a capacity of fourteen million gallons per day. The plant utilizes sodium hypochlorite as a disinfectant. The plant came on line August of 2008 and is named the Jerry Plott Plant. The 14 million gallon per day plant theoreticaly gives the city a capacity of 60 MGD to meet future growth.                                                                                                                                                                                    The city council approved a sodium hypochlorite project to be installed at the Ed Love Plant and expected implimintation day is July of 2009. the city will comply with all laws and regulations that have been passed that effect the treatment facilities.
